name: pidstat
usage: pidstat [ -d ] [ -H ] [ -h ] [ -I ] [ -l ] [ -R ] [ -r ] [ -s ] [ -t ] [ -U [ username ] ] [ -u ] [ -V ] [ -v ] [ -w ] [ -C comm ] [ -G process_name ] [ --dec={ 0 | 1 | 2 } ] [ --human ] [ -p { pid[,...] | SELF | ALL } ] [ -T { TASK | CHILD | ALL } ] [ interval [ count ] ] [ -e program args ]

options.description: Specify the number of decimal places to use (0 to 2, default is 2).
Print sizes in human-readable format (e.g., 1.0k, 1.2M, etc.).
Display only tasks whose command name includes the string `comm`. This can be a regular expression.
Display only processes whose command name includes the string `process_name`. This can be a regular expression.
Report I/O statistics (kernels 2.6.20 and later only).
Execute program with given arguments and monitor it with `pidstat`. Stops when the program terminates.
Display timestamp in seconds since the epoch.
Display all activities horizontally on a single line, with no average statistics at the end of the report.
In an SMP environment, divide task CPU usage by the total number of processors.
Display the process command name and all its arguments.
Select tasks for which statistics are reported. Accepts `pid[,...]`, `SELF`, or `ALL`.
Report page faults and memory utilization.
Report realtime priority and scheduling policy information.
Report stack utilization.
Specify what to monitor: TASK (individual tasks), CHILD (tasks and their children), or ALL.
Display statistics for threads associated with selected tasks.
Report CPU utilization.
Print version number then exit.
Report values of some kernel tables.
Report task switching activity (kernels 2.6.23 and later only).
